results.headline: A Patagonian Dream of a Day at the End of a Life
results.summary_short: Portentous dreams infiltrate the Argentine director Carlos Sorín’s film “The Window.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Window

results.headline: In Malaysia, Everyday Rhythms
results.summary_short: Liew Seng Tat’s film is providing a delicious, quirky example of what the camera can do just by being an unhurried observer.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Flower in the Pocket

results.headline: Two Men on the Road, Together and Yet Alone
results.summary_short: “Eldorado” is a road movie that poignantly juggles absurdism and melancholy.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Eldorado

results.headline: Enigmatic Killer Finds Like Soul in Unlikely Place
results.summary_short: “The Merry Gentleman” is an austere, nearly pitch-perfect character study of two mismatched yet ideally matched souls.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Merry Gentleman

results.headline: Planetary Peril
results.summary_short: In this 3-D animated space picture, humans invade a peace-loving planet populated by squiggly beings.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Battle for Terra

results.headline: Fame Deferred
results.summary_short: A number of first-timers were involved in “Jazz in the Diamond District,” so perhaps they can be forgiven for not realizing how tired this general plotline is.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jazz in the Diamond District

results.headline: I, Mutant, Red in Face and Claw
results.summary_short: “X-Men Origins: Wolverine,” with its ungainly, geeky title and its relatively trim running time, helps explain just what makes this guy so intriguing and unusual.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of X-Men Origins: Wolverine

results.headline: Self-Esteem Bustier
results.summary_short: Students in the fall 2007 class at Academy of Burlesque in Seattle are profiled in this blandly well-intentioned documentary.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Wink and A Smile

results.headline: A Ghost Story With Discreet Tingles
results.summary_short: “The Skeptic” wants to be a haunted house movie for grownups, if such an oxymoron is possible.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Skeptic

results.headline: A Seamy Side of Vienna, With No Waltzes Included
results.summary_short: “Revanche” is a tidy, glum thriller that aims for a tone of sour humanism, perched just on the near edge of cynical despair.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Revanche

results.headline: When Self-Interest Clashes With Unruly Desire
results.summary_short: With “Three Monkeys,” Nuri Bilge Ceylan trains his cool, detached sensibility on a ripe and pulpy melodrama that might have originated in a James M. Cain novel.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Three Monkeys

results.headline: Mystery Man on a Mission in Spain, Meeting Other Mystery People
results.summary_short: “The Limits of Control” is a Minimalist exercise in the key of cool from Jim Jarmusch.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Limits of Control

results.headline: Cold, Hard Science
results.summary_short: This reserved, tough-minded documentary sinks something of the feel and routine of a scientific expedition into your bones.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ice People

results.headline: Looking Deep Into the Abyss of a Troubled Mother’s Heart
results.summary_short: “Home” is an extremely personal film that has the tone and structure of a diary.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Home

results.headline: He Loved Too Often but Not Wisely
results.summary_short: “Ghosts of Girlfriends Past” is a junky-looking romantic comedy that’s neither remotely romantic nor passably comic.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ghosts of Girlfriends Past

results.headline: Campfire Horror, Through a Kaleidoscope
results.summary_short: The filmmaker Graham Reznick arrives with a bang in his feature debut, the experimental horror film “I Can See You.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I Can See You

results.headline: Happily Married, but Still a Stalker’s Perfect Target
results.summary_short: “Obsessed,” a clanking, low-rent imitation of “Fatal Attraction,” lacks both the original film’s imagination and moral ambiguity.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Obsessed

results.headline: Take Earth, Add Monsters and Soldiers, Then Toss
results.summary_short: The “Mutant Chronicles” experience can be simulated by jumbling together memories of “Aliens,” “Blade 2,” and the Uwe Boll oeuvre, then turning your mental brightness setting to Indistinguishable Gloom.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mutant Chronicles

results.headline: Violence Embodied in a Boxer’s Rise and Fall
results.summary_short: Mike Tyson describes the murderous clarity he carried into the ring in “Tyson.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tyson

results.headline: A Musical Journey
results.summary_short: “Throw Down Your Heart” chronicles the African pilgrimage of the American banjo virtuoso Béla Fleck in search of the origins of his chosen instrument.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Throw Down Your Heart
